06.01.question: Entities are a person, place, or thing.

06.02.question: Entities are further designed with attributes.

06.03.question: An entity is the basic building block for a data model.

06.04.question: Relationships are drawn with lines showing cardinality and plurality.

06.05.A.choice: Is a use-case diagram enhanced graphically to show data and process modeling

06.05.B.choice: Is a graphical display of the processes in a business system

06.05.C.choice: Is a high-level CASE diagram of data modeling used in business systems

06.05.D.choice: Is a picture that shows the information that is created, stored, and used by a business system

06.05.E.choice: Is an illustration of external data flows to and from a business systems

06.06.question: With an ERD, the diagrams are drawn in a sequential order – from top to bottom.

06.07.question: On an ERD, data elements are described as singular (1:1); plurals (1:N); or didactic (M:N).

06.08.question: Which would likely be an entity on a car insurance ERD?

06.09.question: In an entity called STUDENT, you might find attributes of Student-ID, Last-Name, First-Name and cell-phone.

06.10.question: Entity Relationship Diagrams show relationships between entities that are what?

06.10.E.choice: In line with the business rules and processing

06.11.question: An ERD is a picture that shows how data and information is processed and transformed by a business system.

06.12.question: Which would NOT likely be an attribute of an entity called "Student"?

06.13.question: A(n) _____ entity cannot exist without the presence of another entity or has an identifier that is based on another entity's attribute.

06.14.question: ERDs and DFDs are two techniques for process modeling.

06.15.question: On an ERD, data elements are listed alphabetically with a cross listing to the processes that manipulate them.

06.16.question: On an ERD, processes are listed alphabetically with relationship connections drawn between processes.

06.17.question: On an ERD, data elements are listed together and place inside boxes called entities.

06.18.A.choice: When an entity comes from an external source (aka 'external entity')

06.18.B.choice: When there is only one entity for a data process model

06.18.C.choice: When an entity can exist without the help of another entity

06.18.D.choice: Where the entity identifier is also the primary key

06.18.E.choice: When a child requires attributes from the parent

06.19.question: A data model can do what?

06.19.A.choice: Illustrate return-on-investment, break-even point, and economic feasibility

06.19.B.choice: Be used as a logical data model in analysis and as a physical data model in design

06.19.C.choice: Only be used with JAD sessions

06.19.D.choice: Only be used in BPR situations

06.19.E.choice: Represent actions or processes that occur in the to-be system

06.20.question: Relationships are some type of information that is captured about entities.

06.21.question: During the analysis phase logical data models are created.

06.22.question: Data modeling is an iterative process.

06.23.question: With an ERD, special symbols are added to show high-level business rules.

06.24.question: ERDs and DFDs are two techniques for data modeling.

06.25.question: An illustration of the transformation of data into business value is an ERD.

06.26.question: In adding attributes to an ERD, which of the following might NOT be a good resource for attributes?

06.26.D.choice: Through interviews (what users need for reports and processing)

06.27.question: Anthony is working on the cardinality of doctors and patients in a large urban hospital. With the large number of doctors with varying specialties and patients that may have more than one aliment, he thinks the relationship might be noted as what?

06.28.question: On an ERD, data elements are grouped in a hierarchical structure that is uniquely identified by number.

06.29.question: In creating ERD's, which would most likely NOT be a source for entities?

06.30.question: The three steps in creating an ERD are: (1) identify the entities; (2) identify the attributes; (3) identify the relationships

06.31.question: The first step to building an Entity Relationship Diagram is to do what?

06.31.A.choice: Identify data flows from the level 0 DFD diagram

06.31.B.choice: identify the attributes for each entity

06.31.D.choice: identify the processes, data flows and data stores

06.31.E.choice: draw the relationships between the entities

06.32.question: Data models can be either logical or physical.

06.33.question: The last step in creating basic ERD's is to:

06.34.question: An entity is which of the following?

06.34.B.choice: Is a person, place or thing

06.34.C.choice: Is described with a verb phrase

06.34.D.choice: Shows if it can be null or no null

06.34.E.choice: Is the association between two related processes

06.35.question: A data model is a what?

06.35.A.choice: The abstract creating of an ideal system transformation

06.35.B.choice: A formal way of representing the data that are used and created by a business system

06.35.C.choice: The expanded, thoroughly balanced and normalized use case for a system

06.35.D.choice: The mathematical model of formulas and logic used in a system

06.35.E.choice: The model that is produced by extreme programming

06.36.question: In an entity called STUDENT, you might find attributes of PROFESSOR-ID, Last-Name, First-Name and CLASSROOM.

06.38.question: What type of process is creating an ERD?

06.39.question: The three major parts of an ERD diagram are what?

06.40.question: A data model is a formal way of representing the data that are used and created by a business system.

06.41.question: One of the most commonly used techniques for data modeling is ERDs.

06.42.question: One of the first places to start developing Entity Relationship Diagrams is by looking at the level 0 process models (DFD) and the use cases for data flows and data stores.

06.43.question: With an ERD, lines are drawn to show relationships among the data.

06.44.question: Lines on an ERD diagram indicate what?

06.45.question: A graphical illustration that shows the information that is created, stored, and used by a business system would be an ERD.

06.46.question: The three steps in creating an ERD are: (1) identify the entities; (2) identify the processes; (3) identify the relationships

06.47.question: Jack is developing an ERD for a small dental practice office patient record system. The dental practice has three dentists, six hygienists, and many patients. A patient is always assigned to the same dentist for all appointments. In particular, he is working on the relationship between dentists and patients. Should it be which of the following?

06.47.A.choice: 1 to 1, with a modality of null

06.47.B.choice: 1 to many with a modality of null

06.47.C.choice: Many to many with a modality of null

06.47.D.choice: Many to many with a modality of not null

06.47.E.choice: 1 to many with a modality of not null

06.48.question: The lines that connect the entities are referred to as

06.49.question: With an ERD, similar kinds of information are listed together in entities.

06.51.question: An analyst can read an ERD to discover the individual pieces of information in a system and how they are organized and related to each other.

06.52.question: ERDs are drawn in several levels: Context ERD diagrams; Level 0 ERD diagrams; Level 1 ERD diagrams.

06.53.question: An entity is described by an action verb.

06.54.question: You have entities of ITEM, SOLD-ITEM, SALE and PAYMENT. Which most likely is NOT a relationship?

06.55.question: Modality refers to which of the following?

06.55.A.choice: Relationships of one-to-one; one-to-many; or many-to-many

06.55.B.choice: The number of attributes generated by an entity

06.55.C.choice: Whether the entity has a unique identifier (aka 'primary key') or a concatenated identifier (aka 'composite key')

06.55.D.choice: The hierarchical structure that was developed in process models applied to data models

06.55.E.choice: Whether and entity can exist with or without a related instance in the related entity

06.56.question: During the analysis phase, analysts create programming models to represent how the business system will operate.

06.57.question: Which would NOT likely be an entity on a car insurance ERD?

06.58.question: A(n) _____ entity is an entity with an identifier that describes only the entity.

06.59.question: ERDs can be quite complex and might have hundreds or thousands of entities.

06.60.question: Information in the data dictionary is called what?

06.61.question: An ERD is a picture which shows the information that is ________ by a business system.

06.63.question: On an ERD, similar kinds of information are listed together and placed inside boxes called data containers.

06.64.question: In defining the data characteristics of Universal Product Codes, we might describe them as twelve characters made up of digits – numeric only.
